Homework (due 0221)

Complete these for Wednesday, February 21. Show work that justifies your answers for full credit.

  1. Give parametric equations for the following lines:

    1. the line through \((2,3)\) at \(t=0\) and \((4,5)\) at \(t=1.\)

      \((x,y)=(2+2t,3+2t)\)

    2. the line through \((-1,7)\) at \(t=0\) and \((3,-5)\) at \(t=1.\)

      \((x,y)=(-1+4t,7-12t)\)

  2. Give parametric equations for the following lines:

    1. the line through \((1,-1)\) and \((-1,1)\).

      The answer where the line goes through \((1,-1)\) at \(t=0\) and through \((-1,1)\) at \(t=1\) is \((x,y)=(1-2t,-1+2t).\)

    2. the line through \((2,3)\) and \((4,3)\)

      The answer where the line goes through \((2,3)\) at \(t=0\) and through \((4,3)\) at \(t=1\) is \((x,y)=(2+2t,3+0t).\)

    3. the line through \((-1,2)\) that has slope \(m=3\)

      Using the slope \(m=3\), we can find another point \((0,5)\) on the graph at a run \(1\) right and rise \(3\) up from \((-1,2).\) The answer where the line goes through \((-1,2)\) at \(t=0\) and through \((0,5)\) at \(t=1\) is \((x,y)=(-1+t,2+3t).\)

    4. the vertical line through \((1,2)\)

      Another point on this vertical line is \((1,3)\). The answer where the line goes through \((1,2)\) at \(t=0\) and through \((1,3)\) at \(t=1\) is \((x,y)=(1+0t,2+1t).\)

  3. For the lines with the following parametric equation (i) find the point where \(t=0\), (ii) find the point where \(t=1\), (iii) find the slope of the line, (iv) find the inclination of the line, rounded to the nearest degree, (v) find the \(x\)-intercept, if exists, and (vi) find the \(y\)-intercept, if it exists.

    1. \((x,y)=(1+2t,3-2t)\)

      1. At \(t=0\), we get the point \((1,3).\)
      2. At \(t=1\), we get the point \((3,1).\)
      3. We can read a run of \(2\) versus a rise of \(-2\) as the coefficients of \(t\). Thus the slope is \(\frac{-2}{2}\), which is just \(-1.\)
      4. Since the slope is negative, the inclination is obtuse; the inclination is \(180^\circ + \tan^{-1}(-1)=135^\circ.\)
      5. The \(x\)-intercept occurs at the point when \(3-2t=0\). Thus \(t=3/2\), and so the \(x\)-intercept is \((4,0).\)
      6. The \(y\)-intercept occurs at the point when \(1+2t=0\). Thus \(t=-1/2\), and so the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,4).\)

    2. \((x,y)=(3-2t,5-t)\)

      1. At \(t=0\), we get the point \((3,5).\)
      2. At \(t=1\), we get the point \((1,4).\)
      3. We can read a run of \(-2\) versus a rise of \(-1\) as the coefficients of \(t\). Thus the slope is \(\frac{-1}{-2}\), which is just \(\frac{1}{2}.\)
      4. Since the slope is positive, the inclination is acute; the inclination is \(\tan^{-1}(1/2)\approx 27^\circ.\)
      5. The \(x\)-intercept occurs at the point when \(5-t=0\). Thus \(t=5\), and so the \(x\)-intercept is \((-7,0).\)
      6. The \(y\)-intercept occurs at the point when \(3-2t=0\). Thus \(t=3/2\), and so the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,7/2).\)

    3. \((x,y)=\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{3}{4}t,-\frac{3}{2}+\frac{5}{4}t\right)\)

      1. At \(t=0\), we get the point \((1/2,-3/2).\)
      2. At \(t=1\), we get the point \((-1/4,-1/4).\)
      3. We can read a run of \(-3/4\) versus a rise of \(5/4\) as the coefficients of \(t\). Thus the slope is \(\frac{5/4}{-3/4}\), which is just \(-\frac{5}{3}.\)
      4. Since the slope is negative, the inclination is obtuse; the inclination is \(180^\circ + \tan^{-1}(-5/3)=127^\circ.\)
      5. The \(x\)-intercept occurs at the point when \(-\frac{3}{2}+\frac{5}{4}t=0.\) Thus \(t=6/5\), and so the \(x\)-intercept is \((-2/5,0).\)
      6. The \(y\)-intercept occurs at the point when \(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{3}{4}t=0\). Thus \(t=2/3\), and so the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-2/3).\)

    4. \((x,y)=(\sqrt{2}+t,\frac{\pi}{2}+\pi t)\)

      1. At \(t=0\), we get the point \((\sqrt{2},\frac{\pi}{2}).\)
      2. At \(t=1\), we get the point \((\sqrt{2}+1,\frac{3\pi}{2}).\)
      3. We can read a run of \(1\) versus a rise of \(\pi\) as the coefficients of \(t\). Thus the slope is \(\frac{\pi}{1}\), which is just \(\pi.\)
      4. Since the slope is positive, the inclination is acute; the inclination is \(\tan^{-1}(\pi)\approx 72^\circ.\)
      5. The \(x\)-intercept occurs at the point when \(\frac{\pi}{2}+\pi t=0\). Thus \(t=-1/2\), and so the \(x\)-intercept is \((\sqrt{2}-\frac{1}{2},0).\)
      6. The \(y\)-intercept occurs at the point when \(\sqrt{2}+t=0\). Thus \(t=-\sqrt{2}\), and so the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,\frac{\pi}{2}-\pi\sqrt{2}).\)

    5. \((x,y)=(3,t)\)

      1. At \(t=0\), we get the point \((3,0).\)
      2. At \(t=1\), we get the point \((3,1).\)
      3. This is a vertical line, so it has no slope.
      4. Since this is a vertical line, the inclination is \(90^\circ.\)
      5. The \(x\)-intercept occurs at the point when \(t=0\). Thus the \(x\)-intercept is \((3,0).\)
      6. The \(y\)-intercept occurs at the point when \(3=0\), which is impossible. There is no \(y\)-intercept.

    6. \((x,y)=(2t-5,0)\)

      1. At \(t=0\), we get the point \((2,0).\)
      2. At \(t=1\), we get the point \((-3,0).\)
      3. This is the \(x\)-axis, a horizontal line. Thus it has a slope of \(0.\)
      4. Since this is a horizontal line, the inclination is \(0^\circ.\)
      5. This is the \(x\)-axis, so every point on this line is an \(x\)-intercept.
      6. The \(y\)-intercept occurs at the point when \(2t-5=0\). Thus \(t=5/2\), and so the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,0).\)

  4. Give parametric equations for the line through the points \(A(0,2)\) and \(B(3,7)\) and
    1. Find the point that is halfway from \(A\) to \(B\).
    2. Find the point that is one-third the way from \(A\) to \(B\).
    3. Find the point to the left of \(A\) that is just as far from \(A\) as \(B\) is.
    4. Find the point to the right of \(B\) that is twice as far from \(B\) as \(A\) is.

    Parametric equations for the line that goes through \(A(0,2)\) at \(t=0\) and through \(B(3,7)\) at \(t=1\) is \((x,y)=(0+3t,2+5t).\)

    1. The point halfway from \(A\) to \(B\) has a \(t\)-value of \(1/2\). When \(t=1/2\), we get the point \((3/2,9/2).\)
    2. The point one-third of the way from \(A\) to \(B\) has a \(t\)-value of \(1/3\). When \(t=1/3\), we get the point \((1,11/3).\)
    3. The point to the left of \(A\) that is just as far from \(A\) as \(B\) is has a \(t\)-value of \(t=-1\). When \(t=-1\), we get the point \((-3,-3).\)
    4. The point to the right of \(B\) that is twice as far from \(B\) as \(A\) is has a \(t\)-value of \(t=3\). When \(t=3\), we get the point \((9,17).\)
